text: there's been a royal decree in Saudi
Arabia that seems like it's good news
for women that is it in Saudi Arabia a
royal decree said that women over the
age of 21 can apply for a passport and
travel without the permission of a male
guardian the Saudi guardianship system
says that all women need a guardian or a
male authority figure to make crucial
decisions for them so that could be a
father it could be a husband male
relative and in some cases even your son
the passport and the travel was one of
the announcements but there were others
as well
women can register marriages and also
register divorces and that was also seen
as like a step in dismantling this
guardianship system we've seen big
changes in the guardianship system in
Saudi Arabia in the past twelve months
we've seen women being able to attend
football matches for the first time and
also they've been allowed to drive it's
been an excited response on Saudi social
media lots of lots of hashtags going
viral on Twitter
lots of memes popping up as well of you
know women running to the airport with
dozens of bags but there's also been a
serious turn to the conversation people
pointing out to the rules that still
exist one being that women still need
permission to marry they need permission
to live on their own they also need
permission to leave care facilities so
domestic abuse shelters you still need a
man to sign a paper to say that you are
allowed to leave one of those facilities
the directive of Watson seen behind this
is a 33 year old Crown Prince his name's
Muhammad bin Salman and he's been seen
as this modernizing force he's talked
about women's economic empowerment he
has some goals pitched for 2030 where he
wants to increase women in the workplace
however people have been pointing out
that a lot of the female activists that
have been campaigning for the rights of
women in Saudi Arabia either detained or
they've left the country like Lou Jane
Al Hilal she's being detained in a Saudi
prison she was seen as a lead campaigner
for getting women the right to drive in
the country but human rights groups are
really concerned about how she's being
treated in prison right now Saudi
Arabia's been under the spotlight in the
past 12 months when it comes to human
rights abuses there was the killing of
Jamal khashoggi who was a journalist and
that happened in a Saudi consulates in
Istanbul that caused a global outcry
lots of women's rights activists about a
dozen have been arrested in the past 12
months Allah also so that's been that's
put the spotlight again on Saudi Arabia
about what it means for women's rights
in the country and the global gender
index of 2018 said that Saudi Arabia was
one of the 10 worst countries in which
to be a woman so all of that combined
together has created this atmosphere of
Saudi really being made to answer
questions when it comes to gender
equality
